docs.lead_paragraph: Completing an extraordinary metamorphosis from political neophyte to polished candidate, Hillary Rodham Clinton -- the first first lady ever to run for office -- defeated Representative Rick Lazio yesterday in a closely fought race for Daniel Patrick Moynihan's Senate seat from New York. If Mrs. Clinton brings to the Senate the intelligence and energy that she brought to her campaign, she should make a worthy successor to the estimable Mr. Moynihan, who is retiring after 24 honorable years of service. Meanwhile Jon Corzine, a Democrat and a multimillionaire who spent nearly $60 million of his own money, will succeed Frank Lautenberg as senator from New Jersey. Mr. Corzine now holds the dubious distinction of having contributed the most personal money of all time to win a Senate seat.
docs.abstract: Editorial praises victory of First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton over Republican Repr Rick Lazio for US Senate seat from New York; says she will be worthy succesor to Sen Daniel Patrick Moynihan if she brings to Senate intelligence and energy that she brought to campaign (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton, here to attend a regional conference on changes since the end of Communist rule, met today with the Polish President, Aleksander Kwasniewski, visited a new Jewish school and spoke with Polish businesswomen. Today was the first day of her four-nation European visit, which will include stops in Slovakia, Italy and Iceland.
docs.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton, in Warsaw for regional conference on changes since end of Communist rule, meets with Polish Pres Aleksander Kwasniewski, visits new Jewish school and speaks with Polish businesswomen (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Since you speak of ''Elizabeth Dole's campaign'' and declare in your headline that she is ''Running Against Hillary,'' I say, let's see a televised debate between these two consummate politicians charging toward the White House. GWEN LUNDBERG Seattle

docs.lead_paragraph: The Democrats may have strayed off the high road, but they’re a long way from Trump-Cruz territory.
docs.abstract: Gail Collins Op-Ed column previews upcoming Democratic presidential debate; notes race has become more competitive between Sen Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton, resulting in somewhat negative turn for campaign.
docs.snippet: The Democrats may have strayed off the high road, but they’re a long way from Trump-Cruz territory....

docs.lead_paragraph: She’s like family to us all, right? Well, let’s give them something to talk about.
docs.abstract: Gail Collins Op-Ed column notes that there is universal public fascination with Hillary Rodham Clinton, both in terms of positive and negative attention; asserts that Clinton may be one of last all-purpose celebrities in era of increasingly fractured attentions; suggests that interest in Clinton will shift from her personal life to her work only if she is elected president.
